profiles.name: Rania Kettani
profiles.biography: Rania is a Sophomore who spontaneously decided to major in Philosophy after taking Introduction to Logic and thinking, "I didn't suffer through that class to not major in Philosophy." Born and raised in Casablanca's busy streets, her favorite word is eclectic and her favorite place is the beach. She's passionate about life, a fan of good conversations, food, and French literature.

articles.title: AD Foodie: Valentine’s Special
articles.teaser: Here are some last minute Valentine’s plans for a special evening with your special someone or friends.

articles.title: Assigning a Rigid National Identity — Is Morocco Arab or African?
articles.teaser: Whether Moroccans want to call themselves Arab or African is up to them because they can be both. It is up to no one else to assign our identities for us.

articles.title: What’s wrong with Willow Smith’s “Black Shield Maiden” ?
articles.teaser: Black Shield Maiden, in its aim to make visible the histories of medieval African people, ultimately is marred by severe Islamophobia in its depictions of the native Amazigh people.

articles.title: The Best Cafes and Study Spots to Work in Abu Dhabi: Part III
articles.teaser: Study spots and cafes in town for when you need a change of scenery from C2 and BlackSmith: Part 2

articles.title: Mme. Pécresse, not all women in France want to be Marianne.
articles.teaser: As the 2022 French presidential election approaches, the politics of the "veil", an effective tactic in an environment plagued by Islamophobia, has regained momentum.

articles.title: How to Navigate Being a Broke College Student AND a Foodie in AD
articles.teaser: As midterms approach, study spots and cafes in Saadiyat for when you need a change of scenery from C2 and BlackSmith — Part 1

articles.title: We were not able to save Rayan.
articles.teaser: Hope. That was the feeling uniting Morocco for 5 days; irrational hope that the efforts of my government would save Rayan.

articles.title: How to Navigate being a Broke College Student AND a Foodie in AD: Meknes
articles.teaser: A kickoff with my favorite restaurant in town.

profiles.name: Corban Villa
profiles.role: Senior Web Chief and Opinion Editor
profiles.biography: Corban Villa is consistently focused and passionate about global issues. He is committed to creating real impact and systematic change for a world in crisis. Embracing diversity and inclusion in his education, he attends New York University in Abu Dhabi to study effective leadership, critical thinking and modern problem solving through Political Science and Computer Science.

articles.title: Adventures in Data Science with Corban: No Flying into the US
articles.teaser: As the TSA list of individuals who are banned from flights was leaked online, Americans were shocked by a stunning, unheard of bombshell: lots of Americans are Islamaphobic. Written by an American, for Americans (to stop being Islamaphobic).

articles.title: Slice of Home: Filipino Panaderia Review
articles.teaser: The place run and frequented mostly by Filipinos promises to "bring back happy memories of home away from home." We interviewed staff and visitors about how the bakery brings them comfort and a taste of familiarity.

articles.title: Why Students Are Losing Faith in the CDC: A Revealing Analysis
articles.teaser: Find out why many students are questioning the potency of the Career Development Center at NYU Abu Dhabi through a detailed review and analysis of the CDC’s recent shortcomings.

articles.title: Can Academia Keep Up With ChatGPT?
articles.teaser: ChatGPT has raised serious questions about academic integrity and the professional world at large. However, as the world faces growing existential problems, can we afford not to have AI? Can academia adapt to an AI-driven future?

articles.title: Drowning at NYUAD: Finding Space in a Ceaseless Work Culture
articles.teaser: Life at NYUAD never turns off — work seems to bleed interminably into weekends, holidays, and other free time. How do we find space for ourselves in this system?

articles.title: The Turning Tides of Financial Equity at NYUAD: The Case for Increased Transparency
articles.teaser: Based on recent discourse on campus, there seems to be an increase in partial aid students and more and more barriers for lower income students to overcome. What if NYUAD moved towards transparency and open dialogue with its “global leaders?”

articles.title: Beyond the Hype: the Metaverse
articles.teaser: With technology reaching new heights year after year, is this really the future sitting just years ahead? Or is it simply an unrealistic dream of science fiction turned into a buzzword for attention and investment funding?

articles.title: The Banning of Maus
articles.teaser: To ban Maus for being too disturbing is to miss the fact that its disturbing effect is precisely the point.

articles.title: Russia’s Pending Economic Crisis
articles.teaser: What does Russia’s attack on Ukraine mean to its own financial state, and is there a looming ruble crisis?

articles.title: Web 3.0: A New Way To Organize The Internet (And Our Societies?)
articles.teaser: New technologies are reshaping the Web and, with it, the potential of our societies to become more egalitarian.

articles.title: Navigating the Line between Body Neutrality and Body Positivity
articles.teaser: Everyone's journey to self-love and acceptance is unique. Here is an insight into two trending concepts that lay out different paths for you to walk along.

profiles.name: Roudha Almarzouqi
profiles.biography: Roudha is a freshman from Dubai, currently thinking of majoring in economics. She is a published poet, passionate about spreading ideas and thoughts through writing. In her free time, you can find her eating with her friends in D2 or watching marvel movies.

articles.title: UAE National Day, and what it means to many.
articles.teaser: National Day is marked on the 2nd of December of each year, and it is marked in the heart of every Emirati as the day we revive the love for our beloved country.

articles.title: Freej: A Reflection of My Childhood and Emirati Identity
articles.teaser: *Freej* is much more than a show to me; it is a piece of my childhood and is filled with nostalgic memories of my younger self.

articles.title: A Review of Al Raheel | Departure
articles.teaser: "Each one of us is daring in her own way. Each one of us has her own voice and I wanted that to come to the piece. I wanted the piece to be as daring as each one of us is.”

profiles.name: Sidra Dahhan
profiles.biography: Sidra Dahhan is a Syrian-American senior studying History and Film & New Media. She loves writing about migration, food, and digital media, and aspires to take as many Arts and Humanities classes as she can during her dwindling time on campus.

articles.title: One day, all my words escaped and I began to write
articles.teaser: I have had many journals, but for every dull entry I have, there are hundreds more blank pages.

articles.title: Is Nicaragua Turning Into a Dictatorship?
articles.teaser: Nicaragua has been increasing restrictions on dissidents, including but not limited to imprisonment and stripping them of citizenship.

articles.title: Study Song Recommendations From The Gazelle
articles.teaser: Diversify your study session playlist. Here’s a list of recommendations from The Gazelle’s editorial board to get you started.

articles.title: Syria: A Dream, A Room, An Earthquake
articles.teaser: I can not pretend the country does not exist in a state beyond family and memories. I can not just pretend that feeling empathetic about the situation is enough.

articles.title: How does NYU Abu Dhabi teach Migration?
articles.teaser: On a diverse campus in a diverse nation, questions of migration and belonging find their way into almost any classroom. At NYUAD, fittingly, particular classes have been created to help foster open conversations about global practices of migration

articles.title: Growing up in Dubai as a Temporary Local
articles.teaser: Will this country become nothing more than a dream, a fading memory? Will it still be a part of me? How will I allow myself to remember this city and this country in relation to where I have belonged?

articles.title: Ana Bahky Araby [I Speak Arabic]
articles.teaser: It may have an unconventional presence in my life, but Arabic, not just English, undeniably makes up part of who I am.

articles.title: Why do I wear a hijab?
articles.teaser: People look at my hijab as a glaring, one-noted statement, a strong profession of faithfulness or laxity in faith, depending on how I wear it. They take the varying styles of hijab as a variation of faith. I am only a shadow of my faith.

articles.title: Comfort Food: A Taste Of Home … Or Is It?
articles.teaser: What is comfort food? Does it have to be connected to memories of the past or can it be something completely new?

articles.title: A Taste of Home: Emirati Cuisine
articles.teaser: In a rapidly changing nation, Emirati cuisine is a reminder of what home and belonging means to us.

articles.title: A Taste of Home: How NYUAD Students Drink Tea
articles.teaser: Tea is a significant part of many students’ everyday lives. It is a source of exploration. It is a way to attain comfort. It is home.

articles.title: A Taste of Home: An Ode to Orange Blossom Water
articles.teaser: As a pandemic baker, I wanted to venture away from overly rich, dense desserts. One ingredient provided the perfect vessel for experimentation. It was floral, citrusy and aromatic. When used right, it was subtly powerful. It was orange blossom water.

articles.title: Studying Away in a Pandemic Stricken World
articles.teaser: As I sit on a wooden bench in Manhattan and notice that nothing went according to plan, I still feel happy and fortunate and wouldn’t have it any other way.

articles.title: A Taste of Home: The Syrian Breakfast
articles.teaser: Syrian breakfast, to me, is not only a wonderful spread of dishes but a social affair central to families and communities. Not only does it embody the things I miss about home, it is simply delicious.

articles.title: To Catch a Campus Thief
articles.teaser: The seeming increase in campus thefts this academic year has many students concerned. NYUAD may not be directly responsible, but it should take active steps to hold thieves accountable.

articles.title: Global Press Freedom is Under Threat. It Is Our Responsibility to Consume Media Responsibly.
articles.teaser: We have entered a pivotal decade for global press freedom. The pandemic has exacerbated digital underregulation through the spread of misinformation, and it’s important for us to reflect on why we should demand more digital media transparency.

articles.title: Reflecting on the Past and Present: Centering Marginalized Voices in The Gazelle
articles.teaser: From reporting on institutional racism on campus to violations of labor rights regulations and the plight of Palestinians, we delve into The Gazelle’s history, and reflect on the pieces that have historically centered minoritized voices.

articles.title: My Fading Memories of Syria
articles.teaser: After 10 years of conflict, a whole generation has grown up with constant war. But Syrian residents, refugees and migrants still exist — and so do their memories of a time before the war. Maybe this is another reason I hold on so tightly to mine...

articles.title: Rihanna & India's Farmer Protest: A Case Study in Slacktivism
articles.teaser: Insincere celebrity attention is fleeting. It is time we stop relying on celebrity activism and become more conscious of and responsible for our social media activism.

articles.title: The Campus Cat Controversy, Explained
articles.teaser: Are the campus cats an integral part of campus? Should they remain? Should more effort be put into finding them new homes? Students and staff share their thoughts on the most infamous members of the NYUAD community.

articles.title: Riverdale and The Winx Club: Don’t Make Childhood Classics Dark
articles.teaser: Life is not always serious, traumatic and intense. Often, it is fun and colorful. Generation Z could use that reminder in the entertainment industry, instead of the lackluster works that profit off of a generation’s desensitization to suffering.

articles.title: We Need to Live and Accept Bidialectism in a Divided Society
articles.teaser: Bidialectism — the ability to subconsciously switch accents based on social expectations — is stigmatized and viewed as inauthentic. However, the world needs to learn to live with and accept it in a globalized world.

articles.title: Why Students Are Losing Faith in the CDC: A Revealing Analysis
articles.teaser: Find out why many students are questioning the potency of the Career Development Center at NYU Abu Dhabi through a detailed review and analysis of the CDC’s recent shortcomings.

articles.title: Review: ‘Bollywood Superstar’ Exhibition at Louvre Abu Dhabi
articles.teaser: Orientalist depictions of Bollywood at an art institution like the Louvre reduces it to a simplistic musical-dance spectacle that completely detaches the film industry from its history, culture and context.

profiles.name: Avaneesh Devkota
profiles.biography: Avaneesh is a freshman from Nepal, looking to major in Computer Science. When he's not procrastinating on his assignments, you can find him playing League of Legends or consuming copious amounts of Reese's buttercups.

profiles.name: Maheen Eatazaz
profiles.role: Deputy Web Chief and Staff Illustrator

profiles.name: Maryam al Darmaki
profiles.biography: Maryam is a sophomore from the United Arab Emirates, double majoring in Legal Studies and Visual Arts. If you do not find her in the Arts Studios in focus-mode, you will probably find her in the library with her study buddies.

profiles.name: Huma Umar
profiles.biography: Huma is a senior from Pakistan, majoring in Social Research and Public Policy, with a focus on global health, gender studies and feminism in South Asia. You can mostly find her consuming too much acai, frantically dyeing her hair and trying to convince her friends to watch the horror movies she recommends.

articles.title: WINTER BREAK BOOK RECOMMENDATIONS FROM THE GAZELLE’S EDITORS
articles.teaser: Leave behind class assignments and read for the sake of it this winter. Here’s a list of recommendations from The Gazelle’s editorial board to get you started.

articles.title: We Have A Responsibility to be More Intentional When We Talk About Migration
articles.teaser: It would be a disservice if we leave here after four years stuck in a liminal space of not really defending and not really critiquing, without unpacking the inherent racialization of many of the ways in which migration issues are framed.

articles.title: Accessing Mental Health Resources Off Campus
articles.teaser: Seeking help is a daunting and tedious process. This guide provides streamlined information on how to access mental health support off campus.

articles.title: Letter From The Editors: Our Community’s Support Is Crucial For Us To Do Our Best Work
articles.teaser: Not only do we need less bureaucratic hurdles to navigate but we need active, persistent and purposeful engagement from all members of our community — this includes students but also administration, staff and faculty.

articles.title: Afro Fest returns as a welcome celebration of community and collective joy
articles.teaser: Afro Fest, a showcase and celebration of cultures from the African continent and diaspora, brought the NYUAD community together to share and learn through performances, educational booths, and food.

articles.title: How Can We Better Engage With Gender In NYU Abu Dhabi Classrooms?
articles.teaser: Talking about gender is personal and messy, and can even be daunting in an academic setting. Here, we complicate and unpack these conversations in an attempt to build more inclusive curricula and classrooms.

articles.title: Zan, Zendegi, Azadi — Iran Protests As The World Watches
articles.teaser: The killing of Mahsa Zhina Amini, allegedly carried out by Iran’s morality police, sparked outrage domestically and internationally.

articles.title: Meet Nadia El Cheikh, NYUAD’s New Vice Provost for Cultural and Research Engagement
articles.teaser: Vice Provost Nadia El Cheikh discusses her upbringing, her time at university and her past experiences as the dean of the American University of Beirut.

articles.title: RealAD Holds Up a Mirror to Our Community on Stage Once Again
articles.teaser: RealAD returns in person for the first time since 2019 and reminds us of why we have missed seeing it live so much.

articles.title: Pakistan is Flooding: Here’s What You Need to Know
articles.teaser: Pakistan has been hit hard by monsoonal floods this year.

articles.title: Andrew Hamilton Leaves Behind a Divisive Legacy
articles.teaser: Hamilton led NYU through an eventful tenure, but his legacy as NYU President will forever be tainted with his inability to stand with Palestine.

articles.title: How Gangubai Marginalizes the Very People Intends to Center
articles.teaser: Gangubai Kathiwaidi is a mainstream feminist Bollywood movie but unfortunately ends up glamorizing the types of trauma women face when forced into the sex trade.

articles.title: “We want to show solidarity”: Sri Lankans Abroad Support Protests Back Home
articles.teaser: Sri Lankans in New York took to the streets to express support for those struggling and resisting in their home country, which is currently undergoing a devastating economic crisis.

articles.title: As A Brown Girl, It's So Much Easier To Feel Free Outside Home
articles.teaser: In Lahore, you can feel eyes on you constantly. Being removed from home for this long has made me realize how much less anxiety I carry with me, and how much energy I have to give to things when I am not constantly worried about my safety.

articles.title: We Stand with Ukraine. We Stand with All.
articles.teaser: Stand with Ukraine, but don’t stop there. Stand for global justice. No matter the circumstances, illegal war, occupation and annexation should not go uncondemned.

articles.title: 'I Wasn't a Priority':  NYUAD Temporarily Fails to Provide Disability Accomodations
articles.teaser: The university, amid scattered arrivals, has not been able to sufficiently provide accessibility accommodations to disabled students. The Gazelle talks to affected students and assesses the sustained impact of this oversight.

articles.title: 'I Wasn't a Priority':  NYUAD Temporarily Fails to Provide Disability Accomodations
articles.teaser: The university, amid scattered arrivals, has not been able to sufficiently provide accessibility accommodations to disabled students. The Gazelle talks to affected students and assesses the sustained impact of this oversight.

articles.title: That's What She Said: Marriage is a Patriarchal Institution. But Everyone Gets to Fight it On Their Own Terms.
articles.teaser: Malala’s decision to marry brought forth a flurry of hot takes: celebration, joy, frustration and disappointment. But it is unfair to place the burden of fighting the oppressive institution of marriage on a single individual.

articles.title: Meet The New Dean of Social Science: Paula England
articles.teaser: Enterpriser, innovator, searcher, feminist, academic: these are some of the various hats that Dean England has worn and excelled at throughout her life.

articles.title: “We have a Long Way to Go”: Revisiting the Vice Chancellor’s Commitment to Diversity
articles.teaser: Fifteen months after the Vice Chancellor’s renewed commitments to diversity, equity and inclusion, the university claims to have made substantial progress. But many promises remain unfulfilled.

articles.title: Looking Back, Looking Ahead: We Promise to Do More
articles.teaser: The Gazelle has acted as an engine of advocacy and subversion on campus for years. Today, we ask for your investment, to continue our mission of meaningful and intentional journalism to better represent and serve the NYUAD community.

articles.title: We Ask for More: Financial Freedom and Inclusivity Can Not Be A Pipe Dream at NYUAD
articles.teaser: We ask for more on-campus vendors. We ask for more assistantships at higher wages. We ask for more paid summer opportunities. We ask for a temporary institutional fund. We can no longer assume institutional goodwill — we need to feel heard.

articles.title: How to Access Mental Health Resources Off Campus
articles.teaser: Seeking help may seem daunting, or even tedious. This guide provides streamlined information on how to access treatment off campus.

articles.title: Step-By-Step: How to Report Sexual Misconduct at NYU Abu Dhabi
articles.teaser: In conversation with NYU’s Office of Equal Opportunity and Title IX and NYUAD’s Health Promotion and Sexual Misconduct Office, we break down the process of filing a formal complaint and accessing accommodations for survivors of sexual harm on campus.

articles.title: In Celebration of Female Only Spaces on Campus: Labor, Compassion and Emotional Growth
articles.teaser: From AZIZA to weSTEM, this International Women’s Day, it is urgent that we reflect on the importance of female and gender marginalized spaces on campus. However, we must also reflect on the emotional labor that goes into cultivating these spaces.

articles.title: A Guide to the City for First Years (or Anyone Else)
articles.teaser: From transportation and dining to entertainment and navigating the city, the features desk offers you an overview of the favorite places within Abu Dhabi for adventures in the city.

articles.title: As long as Women and Gender Minorities Continue to Disrupt the Patriarchy in Pakistan, There is Hope.
articles.teaser: We are still scared, apprehensive and angry when we step out onto the streets back in Pakistan, but we go out with a greater hope that one day, this resistance will pay off and that our country will be as much ours and as safe for us.

articles.title: Students of Determination Week: Can NYUAD Transform One Week of Programming into an Institution Wide Commitment?
articles.teaser: "Accessibility needs to be something that permeates every single department and every single conversation on campus," reflected participants from Students of Determination Week. What were the impacts of this week? How can it transform the community?

articles.title: Behind the Scenes: The Pakistan Student Association
articles.teaser: With several changes taking place due to the virtual semester, the current Executive Board has taken the opportunity to host discussion based events to tackle significant issues being faced by the Pakistani community.

articles.title: AD Secrets: A Guide to Study Spots in the City
articles.teaser: Are you tired of moving from your bed to your desk and back again? Are you bored of having the same coffee and snacks from the Library Cafe? Here is a guide to different places to study in the city, ideal during remote semesters.

articles.title: How NYU Abu Dhabi Recruits Faculty, Explained
articles.teaser: How do institutional goals of diversity, equity and inclusion play into the way NYUAD recruits faculty? The Gazelle interviewed Kirsten Edepli, Vice Provost for Faculty Development and Diversity, to understand this process.

articles.title: Diversity and NYUAD: Numbers Are Not Everything
articles.teaser: Focusing solely on diversity’s quantifiable nature is not enough.

articles.title: In the Pursuit of Happiness
articles.teaser: Working towards a more content existence is extremely important. But compulsifying the journey to a happier life is counterintuitive.

articles.title: Feminism: Breaking the Binary
articles.teaser: Viewing social issues through a gendered lens inadvertently perpetuates the gender binary in a world which increasingly acknowledges the existence of non-binary identities.

articles.title: The Power of Greta Thunberg
articles.teaser: Why has Greta Thunberg become the primary target of conservative ire? It’s because her rhetoric directly targets the power elite that benefit the global right.

profiles.name: Abbas Raza
profiles.biography: Abbas is a freshman from Pakistan and Canada, tied between majoring in "some sort of" Engineering or Film and New Media. He spends most of his free time listening to his playlist of film scores and watching movies to find new soundtracks to add to said playlist.

profiles.name: Arwa Alabbasi
profiles.biography: Arwa is a freshman from Dubai, majoring in physics and mathematics. She's interested in scientific communication and making scientific knowledge and discoveries more accessible and understandable to everyone. You can find her in the lab, learning about particle physics, or looking at challenging problem sets with friends.

articles.title: Our Learning Community Initiative: a Platform of Community Engagement via Mini Classes
articles.teaser: The NYU Abu Dhabi community hosted bite-sized courses on everything from parkour to knitting.

profiles.name: Yana Peeva
profiles.biography: Yana is a first-year student with interest in both the social science and engineering. When not editing for the Gazelle, she writes meme movie reviews on Letterboxd, book reviews on Goodreads and music reviews on Instagram chats with her friends (because when you don't become filmmaker/novelist/musician, you become a critic).

articles.title: Biggest Experimental Vertical Farm in the World Opens in Abu Dhabi
articles.teaser: Aerofarms opened the largest facility in the world for research on vertical indoor farming on Feb. 15 in Abu Dhabi, in correspondence with the sustainable development goals of the UAE.

articles.title: Music Column: Special Silent Issue
articles.teaser: From its ability to build tension to its place in the anti-art movement, silence in music can be as meaningful and sometimes more impactful than musical composition itself.

articles.title: The U.S.’s Savior Complex Won’t Help Venezuela
articles.teaser: After eight years of economic collapse, international journalists and finance experts have declared that there is almost no chance for recovery at this point for Venezuela. Hear from your fellow NYUAD Venezuelans how they feel about this crisis.

articles.title: NYUAD Campus Architect Passes Away at 78
articles.teaser: Rafael Viñoly, the architect behind NYU Abu Dhabi’s campus, passed away on March 2, aged 78. NYUAD — among other institutions across the globe — pays tribute.

articles.title: Music Column Vol. XII
articles.teaser: New music is scarce in the spring. The Gazelle has done some digging to save you the time for studying, and the product is this week’s eclectic selection of fresh music picks.

articles.title: Should We Watch the Oscars?
articles.teaser: The Oscars have long been considered the leading authority on film and all forms of film art. However, lately it has been riddled with scandal and controversies surrounding the ceremony’s diversity and nominations, among other issues.

articles.title: Music Column Vol. XI
articles.teaser: The music you hear from the front row seats of the first class wagon of the bullet train called “Despair and Test Anxiety.”

articles.title: Has the YouTube/TikTok Alt-Right Pipeline Disappeared?
articles.teaser: Numerous studies confirm users’ suspicions that algorithms of video-sharing platforms promote online extremism. Following the ban and arrest of one of the most famous far-right figures Andrew Tate, the clearcut pipeline appears to have disappeared.

articles.title: Why Engineering Ethics Is More Important Than You Think
articles.teaser: Damage to buildings in Turkey and Syria is alarming, raising doubts about the construction processes and regulations. However, engineers must also be held accountable for the value placed on human life, alongside the state.

articles.title: Response: The Problem with David Cameron
articles.teaser: Students' concerns against Cameron’s appointment is not a revocation of people’s academic freedom; it is an expression of critical thinking to contextualize the problematic ideas which lie at the center of Cameron’s political actions.

articles.title: Music Column Vol. X
articles.teaser: The Music Column is ten, but… its tenth issue is more than 1500 words long.

articles.title: Syria-Turkey Earthquake: Death toll surpasses 20,000 victims
articles.teaser: On Monday, Feb. 6, an earthquake of magnitude 7.8 struck Turkey and Syria. Here is a summary of the international response to the catastrophe, the death toll, the national response, and the challenges both countries face regarding humanitarian aid.

articles.title: Music Column Vol. IX
articles.teaser: Let's start this semester off right with some fresh music picks, an iconic blast from the past and an upcoming gem.

articles.title: A New Spring of Nations: the Anti-Lockdown Protests in China
articles.teaser: Massive protests are happening in China in response the zero-Covid policies in the country. Discontent arose after months of economic and social consequences due to these policies.

articles.title: Your Weekly Music Recs Vol. VIII: Wrapped Edition
articles.teaser: The final edition of the music column for this semester and the year 2022 comes with a recap of all the Weekly Music Recs we enjoyed together, in the style of Spotify Wrapped.

articles.title: Behind the Scenes of Temporary People: Stories of Collaboration and Community
articles.teaser: NYUAD’s fall production, Temporary People, took the form of a multidisciplinary docu-fictive performance, directed by Laila Soliman in collaboration with Faustin Linyekula.

articles.title: Your Weekly Music Recs Vol. VII
articles.teaser: With few releases by popular artists lined up, some upcoming indie musicians shine through much brighter. This week’s edition is dedicated to the artists that don’t shy away from the silence and shadows on the stage.

articles.title: It’s Trans Awareness Week 2022
articles.teaser: Nov. 13 - Nov. 20, marked the annual Trans Awareness Week 2022, which is both a celebration of the transgender identity and a commemoration of all victims of transphobia.

articles.title: Back to the Moon: NASA Launches Artemis I
articles.teaser: The launch of NASA’s most powerful rocket to date, Artemis, marks the revival of the moon missions. Here is an overview of the process, challenges, and implications of this mission.

articles.title: Your Weekly Music Recs Vol. VI: Special Grammy Nominations Edition
articles.teaser: The recently released Grammy nominations stir up speculation about what the prestigious award really stands for.

articles.title: A Night Festival with Music and Art: Raul Midón and Alex Cuba Perform on Campus
articles.teaser: A surprising night souk took place during Grammy nominated Raul Midón and Alex Cuba’s exceptional, first ever  Latin Pop concert in the United Arab Emirates, turning the event into a small festival.

articles.title: Rhythms of Protest
articles.teaser: As the movement against the oppressive regime in Iran develops, its message spreads equally quickly through the Internet in the form of powerful slogans and songs.

articles.title: Eight Dollar Speech: How Much Could a Joke Cost?
articles.teaser: With his Twitter takeover, Elon Musk has introduced paid “free” speech. The chaos may be entertaining, but is putting the entire social media platform on the road to failure.

articles.title: Your Weekly Music Recs Vol. V
articles.teaser: In the 11th month of the year, most of us are in need of a quiet, cozy fall. This week's music selection offers a temporary escape and refuge from the hustle and bustle of the busy Abu Dhabi and Dubai life.

articles.title: Tomato Soup for Future: Is the Latest Trend in Climate Activists’ Public Actions Truly Unfounded?
articles.teaser: If scandal is what makes the media world go around, then the “Just Stop Oil” representatives might have found the solution to rekindling interest in climate activism.

articles.title: Your Weekly Music Recs Vol. IV
articles.teaser: A look back at everything that happened during the fall break (which we already forgot happened) and the past couple of weeks, which were surprisingly busy for both NYUAD students and the music industry.

articles.title: As Winter Draws Near, Here’s How to Explore Abu Dhabi
articles.teaser: Now that the weather is no longer an obstacle to experiencing the Abu Dhabi outdoors, it is time to make the most of what the city has to offer. Here are some fun places in the city, my friends and I have found and started to explore.

articles.title: Your Weekly Music Recs Vol. III
articles.teaser: The Music Corner returns this week with the newest, all-time best and most expected records of the week Sept. 29 — Oct. 4.

articles.title: Your Weekly Music Recs Vol. II
articles.teaser: The grind never stops, therefore the music shouldn't either. Music Corner returns with new picks and news from the world of pop and rock stars. Tune in!

articles.title: UN Report on Human Rights Finds China Responsible for “Serious Human Rights Violations”
articles.teaser: The UN recently released a human rights report accusing the Chinese government of “crimes against humanity” for the treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang.

articles.title: Your Weekly Playlist Recs
articles.teaser: Welcome to the Music Corner! For any of you looking for new music to vibe to during study time at the Library, please enjoy the read.

articles.title: Performative Love and the Power of the Audience: A Sociological Perspective
articles.teaser: Celebrating everyone’s beloved Valentines’ day by critiquing its entire foundation!

articles.title: ‘How are you?’
articles.teaser: A guide to deceptively responding to one of NYUAD’s most commonly used greetings.

articles.title: Pawesome Profiles Volume I: Meet Rocky and Tucker!
articles.teaser: Sneak a peek at some of our very adorable dogs on campus.

articles.title: Crown Prince Wilhelm: a man on a mission or a villain in the making?
articles.teaser: Young Royals’ Season two shows Wilhelm coming for August’s neck, no matter what political, financial or social structures he has to destroy. But is it the morally right thing to do? And will it get him Simon’s approval?

articles.title: The Big 700: Impacts of Record Class Sizes
articles.teaser: The Class of 2026 has a record enrollment of 688 students, far and beyond previous class sizes. What does this rapid expansion mean for NYUAD?

profiles.name: Alya Al Zaabi
profiles.biography: Alya Al Zaabi is a columnist, photographer, and illustrator for The Gazelle. She is passionate about current world issues, including human, animal, and environmental rights.

articles.title: The Rise of BookTok
articles.teaser: BookTok has become one of the leading hobby communities online. Its popularity has led to a whole new generation of readers, but has the platform with short-timed content undermined the experience of reading?

articles.title: J-Term 2023: Exploring Athens Outside of the Academic Setting
articles.teaser: A student's guide to hidden gems in Athens that you must see, despite your packed academic schedules.

profiles.name: Nirvik Bista
profiles.biography: Nirvik is a sophomore from Nepal majoring in Economics. He's passionate about social research and sustainability, and if not found in his suite, look again, he'll be there.

profiles.name: Barry Lin
profiles.biography: Barry is a junior double majoring in Political Science and Economics. He loves food and travel. He is always trying to comprehend life while exploring the world.

articles.title: Green House Case Competition (Sustainability Bootcamp) Launched
articles.teaser: The Green House SIG presented real-world sustainability challenges and potential solutions in its first-ever case competition.

articles.title: Covid-19 Updates
articles.teaser: On nov. 6th, the UAE National Emergency Crisis and Disaster Management Authority (NCEMA) announced the removal of all precautionary measures related to Covid-19. They are as follows.

articles.title: Summer Heat Waves: Climate Change Around the World
articles.teaser: The recent heat waves around the globe highlight our vulnerability in the face of climate change.

articles.title: Everything You Need to Know About WorkSmart
articles.teaser: NYUAD has recently launched WorkSmart, an initiative aiming to improve the effectiveness of communication with the administrative departments. Here is everything you need to know about it.

articles.title: The China-Gulf Forum 2022
articles.teaser: The two-day forum will bring a series of events focusing on the long-standing partnership between China and Gulf countries.

articles.title: Parthenogenesis Exhibition Opens at the NYUAD Art Gallery
articles.teaser: The upcoming exhibition will be the first institutional solo exhibition in the UAE by the Iranian trio, creating a landscape and tapestry of continuously evolving ideas.

articles.title: UAE Hosts Major Golf Tournaments
articles.teaser: Four major golf tournaments were held in Abu Dhabi, Dubai and Ras Al Khaimah in the past few weeks. We speak to a student volunteer to learn more about their experience.

articles.title: COP26 Climate Change Summit: Act Now
articles.teaser: COP26 has brought together 120 world leaders and twenty-five thousand delegates to work towards a sustainable, green future.

profiles.name: Howard Lai
profiles.biography: I am Howard from Taiwan. A person who is passionate about sharing his opinions and love to construct meaningful communications with people from different backgrounds. I'm now a Staff Writer and Communications and am super excited cooperating with amazing people!

profiles.name: Scarlette Jiménez
profiles.biography: I am a Sophomore from Mexico City, Mexico majoring in Political Science. I love reading and watching movies, mainly the ones that make me reflect on humanity.

articles.title: Transparency concerns surrounding Nigerian presidential election
articles.teaser: Tinubu was declared the winner of the Nigerian Presidential election in an election plagued by fraud allegations. He faces significant challenges, including uniting Nigeria's diverse population and addressing security and economic concerns.

articles.title: Political and Social Turmoil in Peru Continues: A Fight for Equality?
articles.teaser: Political turmoil in Peru began in Dec. 2022 but has now escalated tremendously.

articles.title: Political Instability in Peru
articles.teaser: The checks and balances behind the Peruvian President’s order to dissolve the Congress and the Congress’ vote to dismiss the President disclose a deeply divided Peru.

articles.title: Francoise Verges on a Feminist Theory of Violence
articles.teaser: NYUAD hosted a book launch for Prof. Verges, where she spoke on how protection, abolitionism, decolonization, and imagination are related to her book, A Feminist Theory of Violence.

articles.title: Spotlight: Gustė Gurčinaitė, NYUAD’s Newest Rhodes Scholar
articles.teaser: Gustė Gurčinaitė, Class of 2023, has been chosen as one of the two 2022 UAE Rhodes Scholars. In conversation with Gurčinaitė, The Gazelle finds out more about her journey.

articles.title: OSR Launches the Global Collection at the NYU Abu Dhabi Library
articles.teaser: The Global Collection in the NYUAD Library promises a reduction of barriers through the introduction of community-recommended, linguistically diverse literature.

articles.title: Same-sex Marriage is Legalized across Mexico
articles.teaser: On Oct. 27, same-sex marriage became legal across the entire Mexican territory after the state of Tamaulipas approved a referendum to article 132 of the Civil Code, becoming the country’s last state to do so.

articles.title: Mexican Solidarity in Times of Crises
articles.teaser: Once again, the tragedy showed the best in Mexicans. Only minutes after the earthquake, civilians started mobilizing to make sure every point in the city with collapsed constructions had help.

articles.title: Resisting Persistently: Reflecting on the Relevance of Aurat March in Pakistan
articles.teaser: Aurat March is a space for radical empathy and solidarity in Pakistan. In the days leading to the sixth iteration of the Aurat March, our writers reflect on the past and future of the movement.

articles.title: Facing Pakistan’s political turmoil from afar
articles.teaser: Imran Khan’s dramatic fall from office, the political uncertainty in Pakistan, and the living costs of it all.

profiles.name: Stefan Mitikj
profiles.biography: Stefan is a Macedonian junior, double majoring in Political Science and Social Research and Public Policy. He's passionate about climate activism, competitive debating, philosophy, and data privacy. When he's not doing his readings for class, it's safe to say he's translating TED videos or reading a Dostoevsky book.

articles.title: Click for Change: How Social Media Can Be a Force for Good
articles.teaser: Despite its negative connotations in today's world, social media is responsible for spreading hope, support, and solidarity.

articles.title: The Community Listening Session Highlighted Long-Standing Student Grievances
articles.teaser: The Community Listening Session offered the first-of-its-kind space for students and administrators to communicate key areas of concern. Although not all answers were favorable, students received more clarity and support.

articles.title: Biggest UK strike in over a decade
articles.teaser: Low wages and UK’s inflation rate made more than half a million British workers go on strike on Feb. 1.

articles.title: There is no longer a stable, international system. What should be done?
articles.teaser: The failure of international cooperation and simultaneous shocks have rendered crisis management difficult. The world needs fresh thinking and a readiness on the part of significant system participants to manage their strategic rivalry.

articles.title: StuGov Elections — Meet the Candidates
articles.teaser: With the upcoming Student Government Elections, there has been a growing interest in the candidates and their campaigns. The Gazelle decided to sit down with some of them and get to know them on a more informal level.

articles.title: Return to Campus Updates
articles.teaser: A quick recap of the newest RTC updates as laid out by recent administrative communication.

articles.title: Who is Making Covid Decisions? A Spotlight on The RTC Steering Committee
articles.teaser: The Gazelle speaks with members of the Return to Campus committee to shed light on their decision making processes during the ongoing pandemic.

articles.title: In Conversation With NYUAD Hackathon Winners
articles.teaser: Two winners of NYUAD’s Hackathon for Social Good and one of the organizers, Professor Sana Odeh, explain their Hackathon journey and reflect on the experience.

articles.title: Return To Campus Updates
articles.teaser: A quick recap of the newest RTC updates as laid out by recent administrative communication.

articles.title: NYUAD Hackathon for Social Good in the Arab World: Focusing on Quantum Computing
articles.teaser: Quantum computing technologies have not reached their full potential yet. This Hackathon will open up opportunities for creating solutions to contemporary problems, building a new skill set and networking with industry professionals.

articles.title: Breaking — Return to Campus Update
articles.teaser: A quick recap of the newest RTC update as laid out by recent administrative communication.

articles.title: Most Optimistic Return to Campus Updates (Yet)
articles.teaser: A quick recap of the newest RTC updates as laid out by recent administrative communication, including a decrease in risk level and more extensive campus reopening.

articles.title: Return to Campus Updates
articles.teaser: A quick recap of the newest RTC updates as laid out by recent administrative communication.

articles.title: Return to Campus Updates
articles.teaser: A quick recap of the newest RTC updates as laid out by recent administrative communication.

articles.title: Can the Metaverse be an Escape Route for Zuckerberg?
articles.teaser: Mark Zuckerberg is betting everything on the Metaverse. Will his wager pay off?

articles.title: NYUSH First Years Stuck in Abu Dhabi
articles.teaser: The Gazelle interviews NYU Shanghai first year students who are stuck in Abu Dhabi due to China’s Covid-19 restrictions.

articles.title: Introducing the Department of Student Success and Well-being
articles.teaser: The Gazelle delves into core of the newly-established Department of Student Success and Well-being to find out how it operates and how it can benefit students.

articles.title: Return to Campus Updates
articles.teaser: A quick recap of the newest RTC updates as laid out by recent administrative communication.

articles.title: Return to Campus Updates
articles.teaser: A quick recap of the latest RTC updates as per recent administrative communication.

articles.title: Marhaba and FYD: Virtually Around the World, Yet Closer than Ever
articles.teaser: Organizing a virtual Marhaba and First Year Dialogue for the second time in NYUAD’s history is no easy task for anyone, but I decided to take on the challenge and apply to become an FYD Facilitator.

articles.title: Amazon Should Be At The Forefront Of A Plastic-Free Future
articles.teaser: Keeping in consideration Amazon’s market influence and its devastating contributions to environmental degradation and the climate crisis, the e-commerce giant can, and more importantly should, be at the forefront of a plastic-free future.

articles.title: Groundhog Day Life: One Year Later
articles.teaser: This year is the perfect time to pause and take a step back. After experiencing Covid-19, I am more appreciative of life. I have discovered that people who were vulnerable during a difficult period emerge stronger than before.

articles.title: Paid Subscriptions Are The Future. Should We Be Concerned?
articles.teaser: Is the surge of websites asking for paid subscriptions a short-lived phenomenon, or is it a warning of a bigger revolution by the tech giants?

articles.title: Podcasts: A Popular Medium Making Its Way Onto Campus
articles.teaser: With their short duration and potential for intimate conversations, podcasts are more relevant than ever. The newly launched Research Abridged podcast from the Arts and Humanities Division provides a glimpse into faculty research.

articles.title: Disrupting The Vocabulary One Word At A Time: Doomscrolling
articles.teaser: People like to search for negative news so much, there’s now a definition for it: doomscrolling. Has bad news outweighed good news this year, or have people been exposing themselves to the former too much to make it seem that way?

articles.title: It Is Scary How Much “Among Us” Accurately Reflects Living In 2020
articles.teaser: From comparisons of getting infected with Covid-19, to staying at home, to fabricating lies on the news, the game “Among Us” is a mirror of living in 2020. Are these uncanny resemblances why many find it comforting to play it this year?

articles.title: How Google Continually Threatens The Privacy Of Our Behavioral Data
articles.teaser: Google’s monopoly has crept into every aspect of our daily lives, making the company omnipresent.  With time and the expansion of Google’s looming presence, privacy, which should be the default priority, will not even be an option.

articles.title: Pre-Recorded Zoom Classes Intensify Procrastination
articles.teaser: An exploration of why it is so difficult for students to focus on pre-recorded lectures as opposed to online or in-person classes and how their intrinsic nature fuels procrastination.

profiles.name: Prakrati Mamtani
profiles.biography: Prakrati am a freshman from India intending to major in Computer Science with a double minor in Applied Maths and Interactive Media, who believes visualising can demonstrate the depth of words. She loves chocolates and watching movies.

profiles.name: Amal Surmawala
profiles.biography: Amal Surmawala is a third-year Literature and Creative Writing major at New York University Abu Dhabi. She’s interested in all kinds of literature, art, music, and feminism.

articles.title: Barriers to the Bard: Accessibility in Shakespearean Theatre
articles.teaser: My experience watching the Soho Place rendition of as *As You Like It* reminded me why theater needs to be more inclusive and accessible.

articles.title: Is AI Replacing Real Artists?
articles.teaser: AI Art generation has swept the internet in recent months, from niche art forums to mainstream Instagram pages. This new form of content begs us to ask what it means to be an artist and what qualifies as real art.

articles.title: Art Dubai Brings Art from the Global South to the Forefront
articles.teaser: Art Dubai returns in March as a platform of curation and exposure to artworks from the Global South.

articles.title: Of Narratives and Subversion: Dr Arshia Sattar Talks Epics
articles.teaser: Epics are long, old, and usually considered the purview of “tweeded professors.” But they are also tales of journey and transformation. They force us to ask questions about the values that societies hold at a particular time and place.

profiles.name: Ethan Fulton
profiles.role: Senior Opinion Editor and Satire Columnist
profiles.biography: Ethan is a junior from the United States studying economics and, still, just about everything else. You can find him having an existential crisis in Blacksmith and probably planning his next solo trip.

articles.title: Flightless Friday announced as latest sustainability initiative
articles.teaser: Following the recent unilateral success of Meatless Monday, next comes our university’s newest fruitful initiative — Flightless Friday.

articles.title: First Artificially Intelligent Student Joins NYUAD
articles.teaser: This spring semester, campus welcomed a new impostor: a student powered by the currently unreleased GPT-4, out to learn about the world from its most diverse microcosm.

articles.title: Word salad spewing AI makes NYU Abu Dhabi effectively obsolete
articles.teaser: Life at our university has always been defined by carefully crafting words to look intelligent while actually having no idea what is going on. Now that an AI chatbot can manage the same thing, we might truly be obsolete.

articles.title: On The Move: A Climate Future of Displacement
articles.teaser: A hallmark of the imminent climate crisis will be the increasing numbers of people forced out of their homes and livelihoods due to extreme weather conditions. How is it currently being analyzed and who is it most likely to affect in the future?

articles.title: Is “Depoliticization” of Sports a Myth? The Case of FIFA 2022
articles.teaser: Can sports be non-political? Why was Russia, of all countries, not criticized to the same extent in 2018?

articles.title: Effective Altruism’s Moral Reckoning
articles.teaser: The EA movement, aimed at “doing good better” through reason and evidence, has understandably been tainted by the meteoric fall of FTX which was headed by one of its biggest donors, Sam Bankman — Fried.

articles.title: Alien Life Researchers Redirect Focus to NYU Abu Dhabi
articles.teaser: Over budget and with no materials for a large grant, a team of researchers has recently found that the Saadiyat bubble is so bizarre and detached from the real world that it warrants further exploration.

articles.title: American Institutions Survive The Ballot Box, This Time
articles.teaser: The 2022 midterm elections provided a good showing for Democrats compared to expectations and the tough national climate. Clearly, there are limits to how far Trumpism can succeed.

articles.title: Saadiyat Time Loop Syndrome: The Next Pandemic
articles.teaser: According to the Health Center, a substantial majority of students have always suffered from Saadiyat Time Loop Syndrome, with campus running on a minority of caffeinated overachievers. But it seems like soon no student will be untouched.

articles.title: Fall Break Recovery from Burnout Fosters More Burnout
articles.teaser: The nine days we have to do nothing, travel the world, or anything in between is a crucial time for rejuvenation. Why is nobody rejuvenated?

articles.title: “Grade Deflation” and the Shifting Educational Landscape
articles.teaser: In our educational pursuits, are we becoming way too focused on the means rather than the ends? Perhaps, but this says less about personal deficiencies and more about the cutthroat time we live in.

articles.title: NBA Security Theater Brings A Slice of Authentic Freedom
articles.teaser: World-class basketball players are playing on our campus to help further clean the UAE’s global image. But we can’t see them or go to the gym without going through the U.S. Transportation Security Agency. Has freedom come too far?

articles.title: Glass Ceilings & Giorgia Meloni
articles.teaser: Italy has elected their first female Prime Minister, who sees Benito Mussolini as inspiration and is likely to form a far right coalition government. Does it matter if the ‘glass ceiling’ is broken by illiberal politicians?

articles.title: Washer Chronicles: Why Abu Dhabi Has So Many Malls
articles.teaser: Working dryers an endangered species? Clothes wetter than they entered the dryer? Shrunk into a kids’ size? All part of the strategic plan for NYUAD to give back to fast fashion retailers.

articles.title: Fall Break Cures Avid Travelers’ Procrastination Forever
articles.teaser: Constantly expecting the other shoe to drop, NYUAD students are experts at getting away with — and thriving on — procrastination … until one genius “low cost” airline caught on.

articles.title: Ron DeSantis’ Cross-State Migration is More Than Just a ‘Political Stunt’
articles.teaser: Sometimes political “stunts” collide with realities like the rule of law and basic respect for human rights. Ron DeSantis’ latest attempt at political theater has shown how dangerous the cruel cynicism underlying conservative politics is.

articles.title: How to Cope Resiliently with Dining Hall Inflation
articles.teaser: Royal prices for common food, with a meal swipe value that hasn’t changed since Barack Obama was President. Here are some ways to cope and not exhaust every form of ‘fake money’ you have.

articles.title: UK High-Potential Visa: Elitism Dons a New Coat, Tailored for Us
articles.teaser: Heard about the new UK visa scheme for “world top universities”? It may be a relief for many NYUAD students with our status as part of the global NYU network. However, it simply reinforces elitist attitudes that have defined the UK.

articles.title: NYUAD Reaches for the Stars: Population Decline Our Greatest Threat
articles.teaser: NYU Abu Dhabi’s campus is becoming more crowded than ever before. But, with an eye on its future, the university will never stop the expansion.

articles.title: Coming to a Periphery Near You: Institutional Neglect and the Jackson Water Crisis
articles.teaser: The lack of running water in Jackson, Mississippi, a neglected capital of a U.S. state, cannot be untangled from decades of institutional neglect that will shape climate disruption worldwide.

articles.title: Roe v. Wade Under Threat: The Dangers of Minority Rule in the United States
articles.teaser: The recent leak of a draft opinion repealing Roe v. Wade has shaken the American political sphere. What implications does this decision, borne out of minority rule, have for the future of U.S. politics?

articles.title: Student Government’s Successful Capstone Thesis in Gatekeeping Overshadows Free Food at Elections
articles.teaser: The dust settled and, as always in the history of NYUAD, no one was happy. With a tumultuous semester ahead as usual, it turns out maybe the secret to engagement does not come from a bakery.

articles.title: The Space Bar SIG Rewrites the Stars at Al Quaa
articles.teaser: Interested in stargazing or astronomy? The Space Bar SIG is growing and may have something for you!

articles.title: Moving the Post-Pandemic Goalposts: New Ways to Justify Incompetence
articles.teaser: “We’ve milked this virus for a pretty long time. But how else can we continue to justify continued inefficiencies and the bureaucratic nightmare of simply existing on a campus borne out of a fever dream?” Vice Chancellor Wickerman asked.

articles.title: Student Runs Out of Minor Tasks to Procrastinate Life Decisions
articles.teaser: Constantly giving yourself new minor tasks to remove any time for self-reflection or taking on important but time-consuming projects is far too easy at NYUAD. Except for one student, who has finally been forced to confront reality.

articles.title: Governments Around the World Try The Saadiyat Model of Economic Stimulus
articles.teaser: Quantitative easing? Old-fashioned. Economics researchers at NYUAD have brought some of the wisdom in our bubble to help indebted world economies out of the pandemic.

articles.title: Superyachts, Rotten Eggs and the Social Contract: Jeff Bezos’ Bridge Saga
articles.teaser: The city of Rotterdam is dismantling a historic bridge temporarily for the sole purpose of allowing Jeff Bezos’ superyacht to pass. Locals have responded with pledges to pelt it with rotten eggs. Are we living by two different sets of climate rules?

articles.title: Higher Education Climate Dialogues: Advancing Collaborative Sustainability in the UAE
articles.teaser: Students at NYU Abu Dhabi and American University of Sharjah will be collaboratively hosting a virtual conference focused on promoting climate action and sustainability throughout UAE universities for the second time.

articles.title: Sustainable Re-Engagement: NYU Abu Dhabi’s New Summer Routine
articles.teaser: Why make anew when you can recycle? Students having to give up their plans to stay on campus is justified as a new sustainability effort aimed at allowing NYUAD to maintain its marketing materials.

articles.title: Student Researcher Discovers Vast Proportion of Alumni Perpetuating the Global Status Quo
articles.teaser: Despite “global leader” and “impact” rhetoric, an astute student assistant has found out that NYU Abu Dhabi is helping its graduates actively uphold the status quo.

articles.title: Virginia and New Jersey Gubernatorial Elections: The Power of Messaging and Memory
articles.teaser: The U.S. gubernatorial and special elections in recent months have hurt the Democratic Party. They must rethink their messaging and policy goals to ensure future wins and claim a larger majority.

articles.title: Programming Board Announces The First NYU Abu Dhabi Virtue Games
articles.teaser: Lacking event ideas that won’t get shut down, the Programming Board has, after much thought and consideration, announced the Room of Requirement Virtue Games, sponsored by Mark Zuckerburg itself.

articles.title: Students Face the Reality that In-Person Classes Also Suck
articles.teaser: Many NYUAD students have realized that the return to in-person isn’t what it’s cracked up to be. We track several students as they adjust to the reality of actually having to give a class their undivided attention for 75 minutes again.

articles.title: The End of Days: Minor Administrative Promise Fulfilled On Time
articles.teaser: In an unforeseen event, an administrative body on campus has fulfilled a promise on time. Here we meet NYU Abu Dhabi’s End of Days and those attempting to save the campus from oblivion.

articles.title: Trouble on the Suez: How Complex Systems Can Fail Spectacularly
articles.teaser: The severe disruptions to global trade caused by the brief blockage of the Suez Canal showcase the perils of our current model based on just-in-time global trade and infinite economic growth. The future only stands to make these events more common.

articles.title: Fighting First Year FOMO
articles.teaser: Perhaps a first year experience should not exclusively revolve around extravagant engagements and travel and we shouldn’t let anything behind a screen influence that.

articles.title: Examinations in the Zoom Era
articles.teaser: Whether through new proctoring technologies and surveillance or an embrace of alternative methods of assessment, exams — a crucial part of any university experience — are now online.

articles.title: NYU Shanghai’s New Campus Reaches Critical Milestone
articles.teaser: NYU Shanghai’s new campus design will accommodate 4,000 students. The project has been making strong progress toward its 2022 opening.

articles.title: To the Moon: The Stock Market’s Absurdity Laid Bare
articles.teaser: The recent meteoric rise in GameStop and other stocks, largely driven by Reddit, shows not only that the working classes can disrupt the financial ecosystem but also highlights the sheer absurdity of the disconnect between the markets and reality.

articles.title: Biden Won. But Trump Might Not Be The Last
articles.teaser: Joe Biden’s victory in the 2020 presidential election has brought justified relief to many. But this fight is just beginning. Complacency will inevitably lead to someone worse than Trump down the line.

articles.title: The Climate Generation: What It Means To Come Of Age In An Increasingly Doomed World
articles.teaser: It is indeed tempting to wonder “why bother?” upon seeing so much that must be changed but is beyond our control. Still, paralysis should not define any of our lives.

articles.title: Night Owls: When Remote Plus Is a World Away
articles.teaser: NYU Abu Dhabi first-year students residing in the Western Hemisphere, seven to 12 hours behind Abu Dhabi, face a unique set of challenges this semester. Amid this, however, comes an opportunity to band together.

profiles.name: Ahmad Savaiz Nazir
profiles.biography: Hi I'm Savaiz from Pakistan and I am a freshman struggling to be everywhere at every time so you will probably find me roaming around campus. Also, I like meeting new folks so don't be shy.

profiles.name: Simon Zhang
profiles.biography: Simon Zhang is a first-year student from Yunnan, China. He plans to read Philosophy and Social Research and Public Policy at NYU Abu Dhabi. He is especially interested in global human dignity initiatives, student accessibility and the decolonization the curriculum in higher education, and inter-religious dialogues.

articles.title: The Drama of Care: Reflections on Our Political Anxiety and Existential Crisis As Global Citizens
articles.teaser: Becoming “carefree”, as humans in a deeply polarized world, robs us of our essence — our being is grounded in our cares and values. We cannot escape politics, as we see in our diverse liberal arts education.

profiles.name: Shahd Nigim
profiles.biography: Shahd is a sophomore from Palestine, majoring in Interactive media with some other minors. She is into Art, Graphic design, music, Film, and I love food and dogs.

profiles.name: Mahlet Atrsaw Andargei
profiles.biography: Mahlet is a creative storyteller and master of capturing life through video. With a background in programming, marketing, and community service, Mahlet is a multi-talented individual who uses her technical skills and passion for making a positive impact to bring stories to life. She is dedicated to capturing the essence of the student community and sharing it with the world in a unique and captiva

profiles.name: Gulsim Azirakhmet
profiles.biography: Gigi is a driven and passionate student at NYUAD, where she is pursuing a degree in biology. Outside of her academic pursuits, Gigi is an avid horse rider and gardener. She is dedicated to her studies and has a strong desire to make a significant impact in the medical field.

articles.title: Music across the world: A guide into Balkan Alt and Indie
articles.teaser: If you're stuck in that awkward stage where you are bored of your playlists, but do not know where to look for new music, this is the column for you. This week, we explore the world of Alt and Indie music, organically grown in the Balkan region.

profiles.name: Shyalina Muthumudalige
profiles.biography: Shyalina is a Junior from Sri Lanka, majoring in Music and minoring in Political Science. She is passionate about education and the arts and the ways in which they intersect. She loves animals and will be happy to share any one of the millions of photos she has of her sausage doggos.

articles.title: Decoding NYUAD’s 2019-2020 financial disclosures
articles.teaser: Who are the highest earners at NYUAD? And how much do NYUAD’s highest-paid individuals earn? Has NYUAD reported positive or negative income?

articles.title: What’s up with all the cows? De-Mystifying the Writing Center
articles.teaser: While focused on one-on-one consultation sessions with peer tutors and Writing instructors, NYU Abu Dhabi’s Writing Center does so much more to help students.

articles.title: Your sign to study away at NYU Prague
articles.teaser: Despite the hassle of securing a visa, and fear of missing out on the New York experience, studying away in Prague was the best decision I made.

articles.title: Extremists or Impoverished? How the Rajapakse regime has hidden behind the veil of terrorism for over a decade
articles.teaser: The rampant repression Sri Lankan citizens are facing as they protest against dire economic hardships has been building for years as the Rajapakse regime has built an oppressive state in the pretense of national security.

profiles.name: Andy Xu
profiles.biography: Andy Xu is a freshman student from Shenzhen, China. He plans to double major in Film and New Media and Social Research and Public Policy. He is an incurable soda drink lover and a crazy fan of FC Barcelona. He loves Quentin Tarantino's movies and Game of Thrones.

articles.title: A List of Two-credit Classes You Should Take
articles.teaser: Here’s a quick overview of two-credit classes you can take when you have a chill semester or want to simply explore the liberal arts education of NYUAD.

profiles.name: Ibad Hasan
profiles.biography: Hi! I am a double major in Film and Literature, from Pakistan. My favourite hobby is bombarding my friends with film recommendations at all times.

articles.title: Response: The Problem with David Cameron
articles.teaser: Students' concerns against Cameron’s appointment is not a revocation of people’s academic freedom; it is an expression of critical thinking to contextualize the problematic ideas which lie at the center of Cameron’s political actions.

articles.title: The Hidden Costs of ChatGPT
articles.teaser: As ChatGPT sweeps its influence across academia, we must reflect on what this means for our future as students, and what its popularity says about the learning strategies mobilized by academic institutions.

articles.title: Tales of Karachi: the city by the sea
articles.teaser: “We took it upon ourselves to excavate these stories of Karachi, for a comfort and an escapism that allowed us to imagine our city as we wanted it to be, with all its complexities and paradoxes.”

articles.title: Joyland: The Politics of Censorship and ‘Joy’ in Pakistan
articles.teaser: The overturn of Joyland’s ban in Pakistani cinemas showcases a rare glimmer of hope in progressive filmmaking, but much work still needs to be done to combat censorship and corruption.

articles.title: Holistic Well-being on Campus: The Dangers of Universalizing Diverse Experiences
articles.teaser: Institutions tend to rely on students’ own creativity and innovation in setting up initiatives related to physical health and wellness. Such education must fully be the responsibility of bodies that claim to look after students’ holistic well-being.

articles.title: AD Secrets: 11 Things To Do On Hamdan Street On a Budget
articles.teaser: A trip to Hamdan Street is always unpredictable: each corner subsumes in itself a story of its own, awaiting new adventure seekers.

articles.title: CDC’s Indifference To The Arts: Myth Or Reality?
articles.teaser: Are the lack of opportunities for A&H majors simply an effect of the CDC’s disinterest in the division or a consequence of the unconventional and varied career paths people in the A&H tend to pursue?

articles.title: The Travails of Communication at NYU Abu Dhabi
articles.teaser: Stemming from understaffed departments, NYU Abu Dhabi’s lackluster communication unduly puts the onus of keeping the student body informed on the Student Government and unruly Facebook groups, causing much anxiety and confusion.

articles.title: Cultural Diversity at NYUAD Needs to Go Beyond Mock Weddings and “Latino” Nights
articles.teaser: Discussing cultural identity from the individual’s perspective allows for greater visibility of the nuances of cultures on campus and bolsters conversation surrounding identity and belonging.

articles.title: The Tehreek e Labbaik Pakistan is the New Face of Islamic Extremism in Pakistan
articles.teaser: With its ludicrous brand of blasphemy politics and on-and-off cosplay as a terrorist organization, the Tehreek e Labbaik Pakistan has consolidated what many political parties can only hope for: the ability to close down cities in the blink of an eye.

articles.title: Balancing Entitlement, Privilege and Criticality Amid A Pandemic
articles.teaser: This pandemic has been an intensive exercise in the process of dealing with loss. We are all deserving of a sense of peace, comfort and security but this should come at the cost of cognizance of our privileges and compassion toward others.

articles.title: Leftist Politics Should Prioritize Lived Experiences over Theory
articles.teaser: The focus on theory has left the lived experiences of marginalized people in the dark within the leftist discourse — something which must be addressed and changed.

articles.title: What's Next After Settling For Biden?
articles.teaser: After barely winning an election that was projected to be a landslide, a Biden-Harris administration can either be the gateway to a new era in American progressive politics, or a catastrophic reverse gear to a third Obama term.

articles.title: Pakistan Is Losing Its Fight Against The Climate. Here’s Why
articles.teaser: Prone to hazardous smog and devastating floods, Pakistan has been declared the fifth most affected country by the climate crisis. While little is being done by the government to address the problem, youth activism provides a glimmer of optimism.

profiles.name: Zlata Hlukhouskaya
profiles.biography: Psychology & Theater major who loves writing, people, and sharing their stories.

articles.title: Where are you traveling this fall break — Small Talk or Burdensome Question?
articles.teaser: While many students are excited to share their travel plans, some of us feel uncomfortable saying that we are “just staying on campus” and having to justify it. Why and how did traveling become an expectation for NYU Abu Dhabi students?

profiles.name: Zhiyu Lindy Luo
profiles.biography: Born and raised in Shenzhen, China but vehemently denying she’s an Earthling, Zhiyu is a junior majoring in Creative Writing and minoring in Political Science and Philosophy. Her life consists of learning 4 (human and non-human) languages at the same time, an obsession with the art of Oh de Laval, and listening to way too much futurism podcasts.

articles.title: Balletcore: A Story of Hyperfemininity, Europeanness, and the Ultra-thin
articles.teaser: Balletcore: the fashion trend of silken pointe shoes, tulle skirts, and leg warmers. Is its potential comeback in 2023 a good sign?

articles.title: Silence or Silenced: The Need for Male-Only Mental Health Spaces on Campus
articles.teaser: Men’s mental health issues are overlooked across the globe and NYUAD is no exception to this norm. Here’s what we can do for the male-identifying students on our campus to provide them with a safe space to embrace their vulnerabilities.

articles.title: The Community Listening Session Highlighted Long-Standing Student Grievances
articles.teaser: The Community Listening Session offered the first-of-its-kind space for students and administrators to communicate key areas of concern. Although not all answers were favorable, students received more clarity and support.

articles.title: Linda G. Mills: NYU’s First Female President Elected
articles.teaser: Dr Linda G. Mills was named President-Designate of New York University last Wednesday. This article discusses her achievements and vision for the NYU global community.

articles.title: Wednesday Addams TikTok Trend: Reviving goth and monster aesthetics
articles.teaser: Does this iconic show, and the subsequent dance trend trivialize subcultures or does it offer an outlet for expression for the underrepresented, underheard and misunderstood? Spoiler alert!

articles.title: Burberry x Minecraft Collaboration
articles.teaser: The British luxury brand has teamed up with Minecraft for an in-game adventure and a new clothing collection in real life.

articles.title: Cuba Approves New Family Law Code
articles.teaser: In a national referendum on Sept. 26, Cuba approved a ratification to the Cuban Family Code. This article reviews the proceedings, background and controversies surrounding the decision.

articles.title: SJP Expresses Calls to Action as four Tel Aviv J-Terms are Offered
articles.teaser: For 2023, four courses based in Tel-Aviv are offered. The SJP chapter in NYUAD called students not to enroll in these J-terms by offering a context of the settler colonial situation in Palestine.

articles.title: Zan, Zendegi, Azadi — Iran Protests As The World Watches
articles.teaser: The killing of Mahsa Zhina Amini, allegedly carried out by Iran’s morality police, sparked outrage domestically and internationally.

articles.title: The Slap that Revived the Oscars
articles.teaser: After Will Smith slapped Chris Rock, Twitter flooded with justifications. It was not the slap itself that interested me. It was the constant weight of performance that I relate to so much. That, and our own subjectivity in the face of comedy.

articles.title: Cultural Clashes Between Korea and China: Lost in Translation, History and Pride
articles.teaser: During the Beijing Winter Olympics, a woman wearing Korean traditional dress represented one of China’s ethnic groups. This act sparked major discussion in both countries, underpinning their complex relationship that dates back centuries.

articles.title: Taylor and Back Again
articles.teaser: I do listen to her, I do like her, but I don’t dare to declare it. I fear the loss of uniqueness. I fear people will look at me and think: just another shallow teenage girl with shallow interests.

articles.title: Leave Eileen Alone: A Proposal
articles.teaser: The Beijing Olympics debate on American-born Chinese skier Eileen Gu prompts me to ask an urgent question: when will we be free from the clutches of identity politics?

articles.title: D1 Opens to Much Enthusiasm, Offering Greater Variety and Convenience
articles.teaser: West Dining Hall D1 recently opened for lunch and dinner. Many students reacted positively to this change, welcoming a more diverse selection of food options and greater flexibility.

articles.title: How the Registrar is Responding to Course Registration Chaos
articles.teaser: Big idea courses, June term and how the university is trying to help graduating students shortchanged by the cancellation of J-Term.

articles.title: Can We Stop Glorifying The Gym?
articles.teaser: From understanding that hierarchy in exercise exists to having gym anxiety, I realized that honoring my body must take precedence over going to the gym every day.

articles.title: Let’s Change the Discourse on Cellulite
articles.teaser: Cellulite is one of the many imperfections in a woman’s body that society teaches us to hate. Here’s the reasoning behind it, and some real talk about its significance.

profiles.name: Shanzae Ashar Siddiqui
profiles.biography: Shanzae is a Sophomore from Pakistan majoring in Economics with a special interest in global macroeconomics. She can be found either looking for or having the nearest available orange juice and/or chocolate chip cookie, reading, or out on a walk.

articles.title: Burnout: What Recent Trends in World Politics Teach Us About Mental Health
articles.teaser: How much is too much? Where is the finish line? Is it predefined or do we have to draw it?

articles.title: The Death of a Former Head of State received no state funeral in Pakistan. What is Musharraf’s legacy?
articles.teaser: An authoritarian dictator, or beloved hero? For some, Pervaiz Musharraf’s represents the tyranny of military rule in Pakistan. For others, a beam of progression for the country into the 21st century.

articles.title: The Hidden Costs of ChatGPT
articles.teaser: As ChatGPT sweeps its influence across academia, we must reflect on what this means for our future as students, and what its popularity says about the learning strategies mobilized by academic institutions.

articles.title: Barzakh Festival Gives Stage to Global Women Artists
articles.teaser: Festivals such as Barzakh are both an absolutely joyous occasion to take time away from work and an opportunity to appreciate small businesses and artists that deserve the spotlight.

articles.title: Has Iran abolished the morality police?
articles.teaser: The Iranian government recently announced the questionable dissolution of the “Morality Police”; what does this mean for the country?

articles.title: On UK’s first Prime Minister of Color, Rishi Sunak
articles.teaser: On Oct. 25, Sunak formed a government in King Charles III’s name, becoming the first ever person of color, Asian and Hindu to reside in 10 Downing Street.

articles.title: Pakistan is Flooding: Here’s What You Need to Know
articles.teaser: Pakistan has been hit hard by monsoonal floods this year.

articles.title: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s Supreme Court appointment: A Major Victory in a Far Bigger struggle
articles.teaser: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s Supreme Court appointment is cause for celebration. But it should be just the beginning.

profiles.name: Miriam Delgado
profiles.biography: Class of 2024. Miriam is majoring in SRPP and minoring in Film and New Media. She is passionate about helping the others in any way she can and sharing the Mexican culture with the world. She aims to contribute to the fight for more sustainable and egalitarian food systems in the future by seeking employment in NGOs or governmental organizations. Since middle school, Miriam has worked on projects.

articles.title: Aftersun and the sunburns from losing a father
articles.teaser: Something more heartbreaking than having a parent with depression is realizing that you had a parent with depression: A brief reflection on Charlotte Wells’ Aftersun

articles.title: A ‘Dive’ into sexual harassment in the Mexican sports world.
articles.teaser: Dive, Lucía Puenzo’s newest film, sheds light on the reality of many female athletes in Mexico who have to choose between protecting their career or reporting their experiences of sexual harassment.

articles.title: Experiences of connecting with nature in the UAE: how I found the beauty of UAE’s nature
articles.teaser: As the famous poet, Jalāl ad-Dīn Muhammad Rūmī once said, “Observe the wonders as they occur around you. Don’t claim them. Feel the artistry moving through and be silent. Don’t grieve. Anything you lose comes round in another form.”

articles.title: Farewells in Ghana: A Photo Essay from my June Term in Accra
articles.teaser: Arriving in Ghana made us forget about the imminent end of J-Term because it felt like something was just beginning.

profiles.name: Cameron Wehr
profiles.biography: Cameron is a junior from San Jose, California, USA, majoring in Social Research & Public Policy with a minor in Computer Science and Environmental Studies.
