He is passionate about computational social research, sustainability and green energy, data science, veganism, LGBTQ rights, South American history, and his pet rabbit Scotty.

articles.title: Are Students Content with the Dining Hall Changes? The Gazelle investigates.
articles.teaser: Campus dining halls recently changed service from ADNH to RCS. How do students feel about the changes?

articles.title: Where is Abu Dhabi’s Air Pollution Coming From?
articles.teaser: Should we be concerned about Abu Dhabi’s air pollution? By understanding where it comes from and how to monitor it, we can take more effective measures to stay healthy.

articles.title: Visualizing 200 Issues of The Gazelle
articles.teaser: Last week, The Gazelle published its 200th Issue. Beyond mere existence, what do 200 issues of The Gazelle reveal? What are the most read articles and what has its impact been on our community?

articles.title: Where Do NYUAD Faculty Obtain Their Degrees?
articles.teaser: What do we lose as an institution when we are not drawing knowledge from spaces outside of the West? The Data Visualization team explores this concept, and how far our university has come in its commitments to diversity, equity and inclusion.

profiles.name: Huda Al-Ali
profiles.biography: Huda is an Emirati senior majoring in Social Research and Public Policy and minoring in Film and New Media. Her passions range from philosophy to mixed-media arts, film, theater and weightlifting! Outside of academics, she spends most of her time writing and reading.

articles.title: Time To Go Viral: Looking into what viruses truly are
articles.teaser: Viruses were, until recently, the talk of the town. These very small creatures have unique characteristics that we need to understand, as they mutate and evolve, even in ways helpful to us.

articles.title: Do Proteins Zip-Line? Exploring Movement Within Cells
articles.teaser: People perceive the way that components of our cells move around to carry out life functions in different ways. Let’s look at examples of these processes and create simple analogies to help explain it better.

articles.title: Enola Holmes 2: A Sequel for Mystery Lovers
articles.teaser: “She likes causing trouble, doesn’t she? It’s as if she was molded that way.” A review of the Netflix film Enola Holmes 2, looking at the plot, its historical references, feminism and more. (Spoilers ahead!)

articles.title: To sit or not to sit? Discussing the disadvantages of prolonged sitting
articles.teaser: Remaining seated for a long time has adverse effects on the body, but there are still some ways to improve your posture in the long run.

articles.title: Why am I not a fly?
articles.teaser: 60% of the human genome overlaps with the fruit fly genome. Here is how studying these similarities is helping our understanding of the human body.

articles.title: Unmasking the Malaria Vaccine and Why it Took so Long to Make One
articles.teaser: A deep dive into how Malaria is transmitted, how the disease impacts the body and the breakthrough R21 Malaria vaccine being introduced this year.

articles.title: Your Cells are Listening
articles.teaser: Let’s talk science and how our cells are affected by our college habits.

articles.title: Is Murakami’s Writing Sexist?
articles.teaser: There are many negative opinions of Murakami’s work on social media, but what I implore you all to do is to take a look for yourself, pick up a Murakami book and be your own judge.

articles.title: The Case for A Constitutional Amendment in Japan
articles.teaser: Japan’s Constitution is perhaps overdue for an amendment, which is up for contentious debate in the country. It is time to look to the future.

articles.title: English is My Second Language: Will I Thrive?
articles.teaser: As an incoming first year student whose primary language is not English, I fear that my words might be misinterpreted during my next four years as a student of NYU Abu Dhabi.

profiles.name: Sarthak Prasad Malla
profiles.biography: Hi! I am a sophomore from Nepal majoring in Computer Science. I have a broad interest in Interactive Media and Applied Mathematics.

profiles.name: Liyan Mustafa
profiles.biography: Liyan is a Freshman from Abu Dhabi, majoring in Political Science and Legal Studies.

articles.title: Silent Sanctuaries: Exploring the Soundless Spaces on Campus
articles.teaser: With an ever-growing population of students at NYU Abu Dhabi, it is often difficult to find peace and quiet outside of the typical library and dorm room setting. Here is a guide to some soundless spaces on campus.

articles.title: A Whole New World… in just 100 days!
articles.teaser: With less than 100 days left until graduation, Class of 2023 is experiencing a myriad of emotions, from anticipation to nostalgia. We interviewed the Class of 2023 regarding their feelings about graduation.

articles.title: The Ultimate Guide To Lebanese Restaurants In Abu Dhabi
articles.teaser: Whether you are an experienced food connoisseur or simply curious about the Abu Dhabi food scene, this guide points you to the best Lebanese food in town!

articles.title: Why You Should Write For The Gazelle
articles.teaser: Often seen as an exclusive community, The Gazelle is exactly the opposite. It is an independent platform for writers from the NYUAD community to express their ideas pertaining to not just NYUAD but also local, national, and global issues.

articles.title: Here’s how to make the most out of UAE National Day
articles.teaser: UAE National Day weekend is around the corner. What can we do to celebrate the holiday, and what events are happening around the country during this period?

articles.title: Navigating Academics, Extracurriculars and Personal Life: How do Commuting Students do it?
articles.teaser: On a campus where many students’ homes are a few time zones away, this piece explores the sense of community for day scholars and commuting students in NYU Abu Dhabi.

articles.title: Finally Unmasked: Students React to Mask Mandate Lifting
articles.teaser: After around two and a half years, the mask mandate has been lifted. How have students reacted to this shift?

articles.title: How to Leave the Campus Bubble on Weekdays
articles.teaser: Although exploring Abu Dhabi can be exciting, it can also feel daunting amid all your other obligations. Here are some suggestions of fun activities that you can fit in the middle of your work week!

articles.title: First Years Met with Unexpected Challenges in Enrolling for Courses
articles.teaser: Students from the Class of 2026, the largest class in NYU Abu Dhabi history, have reported multiple unprecedented complications in their first year course registration process.

profiles.name: Githmi Rabel
profiles.biography: Githmi is a senior from Sri Lanka, majoring in Economics and Social Research and Public Policy. She's interested in migration and migrant justice from, to and within the Global South. She has an unhealthy obsession with coffee and you can always find her with a worn out book she's already read seven times.

articles.title: “I would like to not get by just barely” — partial aid students at NYUAD
articles.teaser: The lack of a clear process to appeal one’s financial aid offer as well as general sentiments on campus that almost all students are on full-aid has led to difficult, uncomfortable, and frustrating moments for students on partial aid.

articles.title: Behind the Scenes of Temporary People: Stories of Collaboration and Community
articles.teaser: NYUAD’s fall production, Temporary People, took the form of a multidisciplinary docu-fictive performance, directed by Laila Soliman in collaboration with Faustin Linyekula.

articles.title: We Have A Responsibility to be More Intentional When We Talk About Migration
articles.teaser: It would be a disservice if we leave here after four years stuck in a liminal space of not really defending and not really critiquing, without unpacking the inherent racialization of many of the ways in which migration issues are framed.

articles.title: Letter From The Editors: Our Community’s Support Is Crucial For Us To Do Our Best Work
articles.teaser: Not only do we need less bureaucratic hurdles to navigate but we need active, persistent and purposeful engagement from all members of our community — this includes students but also administration, staff and faculty.

articles.title: Afro Fest returns as a welcome celebration of community and collective joy
articles.teaser: Afro Fest, a showcase and celebration of cultures from the African continent and diaspora, brought the NYUAD community together to share and learn through performances, educational booths, and food.

articles.title: Meet Nathalie Peutz, the new Executive Director of the Core Curriculum
articles.teaser: Nathalie Peutz was appointed as the Executive Director of the Core Curriculum. Here, she talks about her background, how it informs her work and ideas for the future of the Core.

articles.title: SJP Expresses Calls to Action as four Tel Aviv J-Terms are Offered
articles.teaser: For 2023, four courses based in Tel-Aviv are offered. The SJP chapter in NYUAD called students not to enroll in these J-terms by offering a context of the settler colonial situation in Palestine.

articles.title: RealAD Holds Up a Mirror to Our Community on Stage Once Again
articles.teaser: RealAD returns in person for the first time since 2019 and reminds us of why we have missed seeing it live so much.

articles.title: For Tarek Al-Ghoussein, A Humble Mentor and A Generous Friend.
articles.teaser: Tarek’s influence is woven into the fabric of NYU Abu Dhabi. You have benefitted from his grace, talent and curiosity. He changed the psychic texture of rooms he walked into. We now move forward without him.

articles.title: On Learning to Live in a World Where There’s No Grace To Pause
articles.teaser: My kindness to myself can not be conditional on how well I do on all the metrics I have been taught that define my self-worth. These were the standards that used to define me, without them my being feels boundless but empty. But I am learning.

articles.title: “Clashing”: What Western Media Narratives Surrounding Sri Lanka Miss
articles.teaser: Sri Lanka is hurting — but it faces a revolutionary movement with great potential for change. Leading media organizations need to more accurately chronicle the struggles against a repressive regime.

articles.title: “We want to show solidarity”: Sri Lankans Abroad Support Protests Back Home
articles.teaser: Sri Lankans in New York took to the streets to express support for those struggling and resisting in their home country, which is currently undergoing a devastating economic crisis.

articles.title: Crisis in Sri Lanka: The Consequences of Institutional Neglect
articles.teaser: Shortages and inflation have made life in Sri Lanka more and more difficult by the month. But this situation was not always inevitable — decades of neglect and corruption have met current mismanagement to shape the country’s predicament.

articles.title: Weeks of Chaos: How ResEd Navigated A Difficult Transition
articles.teaser: With the last-minute cancellation of January Term, an overstretched Residential Education staff struggled to overcome challenges of housing more students than were expected. Several students share their experience navigating this challenge.

articles.title: Encanto: On Familial Love and Generational Trauma
articles.teaser: Encanto begins as a simple story but comes to allow for a complex understanding of the emotional tensions within families defined by the traumas of their ancestors.

articles.title: The NYUAD Climate Survey Report, Explained
articles.teaser: The data suggests that large percentages of students, faculty and staff feel positively about NYUAD but that climate is less hospitable for community members of marginalized identities, particularly for People of Determination and Black participants.

articles.title: Expo 2020: Sri Lanka’s Pavilion of Erasure
articles.teaser: The Sri Lankan pavilion not only ignores local exploitation to flaunt an international narrative of exoticism, but also reinforces a hierarchy that Sinhalese-Buddhists are more Sri Lankan than anyone else.

articles.title: Why We Need To Rethink FYD
articles.teaser: The FYD Program is one of the hallmarks of the NYUAD first-year experience. Despite the curriculum’s aims of promoting inclusivity and intercultural understanding, the program has some glaring flaws.

articles.title: I Was Aware of The Privilege of Being A Student at NYUAD. I Didn’t Know It Would Save My Life.
articles.teaser: By virtue of being a student at NYUAD, I am safer than most during a public health crisis that has made crematoriums out of public parks. I am reckoning with that anger and guilt.

articles.title: Funny Boy: Powerful But Inauthentic
articles.teaser: While the movie Funny Boy provides a voice for those who exist on the fringes of our ethnocentric, heteronormative society, the true story becomes inauthentic as its characters are contrived and dislocated.

articles.title: As We Lose Our Study Aways, We Must Rethink Our Narrow Conceptions of Global Education
articles.teaser: Study Away has always been marketed as the backbone of NYUAD’s global education. Faced now with the loss of study aways, we must now reevaluate what it means to receive a global education and whether Eurocentric study aways are imperative to this.

articles.title: If the Community Standards Non-Compliance Report Form Must Exist, It Should Apply to Faculty and Admin Too
articles.teaser: Even if all students follow the current guidelines, it will be in vain if faculty and admin are not obliged to do the same. When different guidelines exist for different community members, it creates a false sense of disconnect within the community.

articles.title: Forced Cremations Continue the Persecution of Sri Lanka’s Muslim Community
articles.teaser: The discriminatory actions of the Sri Lankan government in regards to enforcing cremation have left the country’s Muslim community in a state of uncertainty, grief and exclusion.

articles.title: Not So Fast: Why Covid-19 Should Lead to the Demise of Fast Fashion
articles.teaser: From its environmental impact to ethical concerns, the cost of the fast fashion industry is well-documented. However, the disruption caused by Covid-19 has offered us a chance to forge a different path for fashion, and we cannot let this opportunity.

articles.title: ‘Men Will Suffer’: A Review of Churails
articles.teaser: What Churails succeeds at is drawing the connection between Pakistan’s colonial hangover and its current systemic harassment of women. It shows the immense structural violence exercised against women and how it is justified in the name of culture.

articles.title: How to Ethically Consume Art: The Case of J.K. Rowling and Harry Potter
articles.teaser: J.K. Rowling’s problematic and damaging stance towards the trans community forces us to revisit childhood memories but this time with a critical eye.

articles.title: Social Media Institutions Threaten The Democratic Project
articles.teaser: The imperceptible shifts in our behavior induced by surveillance capitalism erode democratic culture and personal autonomy.

articles.title: Sri Lanka 2020: A Eulogy to Democracy
articles.teaser: "We should not have to compromise on our democracy in order to achieve tangible change,” writes Githmi Rabel of the recent election of an authoritarian government in Sri Lanka.

articles.title: Diversity and NYUAD: Numbers Are Not Everything
articles.teaser: Focusing solely on diversity’s quantifiable nature is not enough.

articles.title: Little Women: An Adaptation for a New Era
articles.teaser: Louisa May Alcott wrote Little Women in 1868. In 2020, Greta Gerwig’s film adaptation sets out to free the original characters from the bounds of Alcott’s time, and does so pertinently.

articles.title: The Legacy of Kobe Bryant
articles.teaser: Acknowledging the 2003 allegations of sexual assault does not diminish Kobe Bryant’s legacy. Instead, it provides a more accurate picture of how his life interacted with that of another life, for all too often, we forget the victim.

articles.title: Navigating Mid-semester burnout
articles.teaser: How can we prevent burning out in the middle of the semester? I discuss my tips and own experiences dealing with burnout.

profiles.name: Naya Alafifi
profiles.role: Deputy Video Editor and Staff Writer
profiles.biography: Naya is a first year who’s hoping to either major in CS or legal studies. You’ll find me either drinking an Iced coffee or crying over Formula 1.

articles.title: You Season Four: Penn Badgley’s soapy thriller is awful(ly entertaining)
articles.teaser: The fourth season of Netflix’s hit-series You released two weeks ago… but is the series still all that it is hyped up to be? Or does the plot reflect lazy writing, causing its viewers to not think too much about what is actually happening?

articles.title: Here’s where you can walk to from NYUAD
articles.teaser: Need a short break from campus? Look around, there’s plenty to do right outside!

articles.title: UAE Drops Mask Mandate – Is the ending of Covid-19 near?
articles.teaser: he UAE joined many other countries in the world on Sept. 28 in dropping the Mask Mandate both indoors and outdoors after a countrywide decline in the number of positive cases.

articles.title: “Ms. Marvel” Redefines Muslim and South Asian Representation: What the Media Should Learn
articles.teaser: Ms. Marvel refuses to conform to demeaning stereotypes of South Asian and Muslim individuals.

profiles.name: Rohan Joseph Sabu
profiles.role: Multimedia Editor and Deputy Web Chief

profiles.name: Shamma Alzaabi
profiles.role: Deputy Copy Chief and Staff Writer
profiles.biography: Shamma is a senior from the UAE, majoring in Arab Crossroads Studies with minors in Literature and Political Science. In her free time she enjoys running away from her capstone, which often includes listening to true crime podcasts and hanging out with her cat.

articles.title: Do We Value Abu Dhabi Enough?
articles.teaser: NYUAD exists at the crossroads of models of global education. Nevertheless, we do not value Abu Dhabi itself as much as we value how well it gets us to other countries. A product of a global university, is this relationship healthy?

articles.title: Why Run on Facebook?
articles.teaser: You would be hard pressed to find an NYUAD student who does not use Facebook. From writing class reviews to searching for their laundry, NYUAD's Facebook forums are a hub for all things campus life that we are becoming increasingly dependent on.

articles.title: Gym Anxiety: It’s Valid And Here’s How To Navigate It
articles.teaser: We are told that we need to exercise for our health, but the prospect of this may be daunting. How can we navigate gym anxiety? What are some ways we can get started in the gym?

articles.title: NYUAD Welcomes Its Biggest Class Ever.
articles.teaser: Upperclass students react to the increase of students on campus as NYUAD welcomes Class of 2026. A school thought to be a small community is growing, and the conditions and amenities to which upperclassmen were used to are changing.

profiles.name: Victor Alves Gomes Nadu
profiles.biography: Victor is a Brazilian freshman planning to major in either Computer Science or Interactive Media. Born at a young age, he became interested in writing as a form of reflecting about life, and he is excited to connect more with the community through transformative and fun writings.

articles.title: Finding Love in the UAE
articles.teaser: Forming relationships in college can be a daunting process for many students. How can they overcome shyness and actively meet people? How can they find time to develop personal relationships and balance academics?

profiles.name: Reem Hazim
profiles.biography: Reem is a junior majoring in Computer Science and minoring in Economics and Math. When she's not working on her assignments or taking an online course, you can find her playing volleyball or taking long walks on the highline with her friends.

articles.title: Is Day Mart actually cheaper? A Comparison of NYUAD’s New Convenience Store and its Predecessor
articles.teaser: Aided by data visualization analysis, we attempt to answer whether NYUAD’s new convenience store is cheaper than the one it replaced.

articles.title: DataViz: Exploring Study Away Course Diversity
articles.teaser: How many courses can Biology or Music students take at NYU’s global sites? How can disparities between different majors be resolved? We explore global education at NYU Abu Dhabi through the study away course database.

articles.title: Visualizing 200 Issues of The Gazelle
articles.teaser: Last week, The Gazelle published its 200th Issue. Beyond mere existence, what do 200 issues of The Gazelle reveal? What are the most read articles and what has its impact been on our community?

profiles.name: Amrita Anand
profiles.biography: Amrita is a junior majoring in Literature and Creative Writing, with a minor in Gender and Sexuality Studies. As an Indian living in the UAE for most of their life, the diaspora is a subject close to their heart, as are most world mythologies. When not overthinking the media they enjoy, they spend their spare time writing fiction and embroidering.

articles.title: Of Narratives and Subversion: Dr Arshia Sattar Talks Epics
articles.teaser: Epics are long, old, and usually considered the purview of “tweeded professors.” But they are also tales of journey and transformation. They force us to ask questions about the values that societies hold at a particular time and place.

profiles.name: Mehraneh Anaraki
profiles.biography: Mehraneh is an undecided freshman dabbling in every major under the sun. In her free time, she enjoys drawing, making spotify playlists, and feeding stray cats.

articles.title: Z-library is Back
articles.teaser: After getting shut down by US authorities, the well-known e-book piracy website has returned to the public access internet with unique domains for each user.

articles.title: ‘Cop City’ protestor shot 13 times by Atlanta police
articles.teaser: “Killing a person who was sleeping in a forest doesn’t make sense to me. We are living in horror.” Environmental activist Manuel Terán was killed protesting against the construction of a massive police training facility in Atlanta.

profiles.name: Sachinta Pilapitiya
profiles.biography: Sachi is a junior with an interest in Economics. He is a badminton and touch rugby player. When not editing for the Gazelle, you will find him reading or admiring nature.

profiles.name: Vimal Minsariya
profiles.biography: Vimal is a junior studying Math and Philosophy. He is always up for any philosophy discussion, or really anything. He genuinely wants to know and understand people, their behaviors, their motivations, etc and connect it to a bigger picture of life and existence, and simultaneously ask big existential questions.

articles.title: NYU Abu Dhabi Takes Flight with New Falconry Course
articles.teaser: The course, which has garnered significant interest from students, introduces the cultural heritage of the region by offering a dedicated to learn the art of falconry.

articles.title: NYUAD is Back To In-Person Instruction
articles.teaser: The university has returned to in-person classes after the initial two weeks of online instruction.

articles.title: Effective Altruists at NYUAD Bond and Do Good at Retreat
articles.teaser: The Effective Altruism SIG organized its first retreat last month, bringing together the entire EA community at NYU Abu Dhabi to discuss questions about doing good and different ethical approaches to world problems.

articles.title: Pink Fitness Games Raise Breast Health Awareness
articles.teaser: The annual Pink Fitness Games were held last week to raise awareness for breast health. Read to learn more about this unique and meaningful sporting event.

articles.title: J-Term 2022 To Only Be Offered in Abu Dhabi
articles.teaser: J-term 2022 will only be offered in Abu Dhabi. We talk to the Global Affairs Committee and students to gauge their reactions.

articles.title: NYUAD Goes Back In-Person
articles.teaser: Students transition to in-person classes for the first time in 18 months. Find out what they have to say about it.

articles.title: Flex Dining Dirhams Introduced to Add Flexibility To Dining Options
articles.teaser: Responding to new dining changes, Flex Dining Dirhams will be introduced for increased flexibility and enhancing students’ dining experience.

articles.title: Students Attend In-person Classes for the First Time in Over a Year
articles.teaser: Some NYU Abu Dhabi students return to classrooms after a year of virtual learning. We speak to some of them to understand their experience.

articles.title: NYUAD’s Model UN SIG Attends its First Virtual Conference
articles.teaser: Adapting to the pandemic-era reality, members of the MUN Student Interest Group attend their first virtual conference in Abu Dhabi.

articles.title: NYU Abu Dhabi Wellness launches the Shared Stories Project.
articles.teaser: The Shared Stories initiative encourages students to collectively reflect and learn from one another through journaling.

articles.title: Opening Doors for Students: The Spring Virtual Opportunities Fair
articles.teaser: Connecting students to employers, the Feb. 25 Opportunities Fair sees its second year of a virtual format.

articles.title: UAE Extends Citizenship to Select Expatriates, What Does this Mean?
articles.teaser: The UAE recently announced a new citizenship law, allowing select expatriates to gain citizenship through an unprecedented process.

articles.title: Spotlight – Saba Karim Khan
articles.teaser: Author, filmmaker and Instructor of Social Science at NYUAD, Saba Karim Khan talks about her forthcoming novel Skyfall and her work surrounding gender inequality.

articles.title: Virtual Exercise: Coaching Through Zoom
articles.teaser: What are the challenges in delivering fitness classes online? How can a sense of community and self discipline be built in virtually? Read on to see what NYU Abu Dhabi’s fitness instructors have to say.

articles.title: Enthusiastic first years plan to create new SIGs
articles.teaser: NYU Abu Dhabi first years share their goals and expectations with the SIGs they are planning to create.

profiles.name: Rabeya Zahan Mily
profiles.biography: Mily is a freshman from Bangladesh studying Computer Science and Economics. She loves painting and she's never enough of having idle times.

profiles.name: Sevinch Rakhmon-Zoda
profiles.biography:
"""I just want everyone to be awesome. That’s all it is. I want everyone to be cool in their own way."" - Tyler, The Creator.

articles.title: Battle of the Bands is Back.
articles.teaser: The most anticipated NYU Abu Dhabi event has finally returned! Here’s an overview of what happened in case you missed it.

articles.title: Tea is a Hug in a Mug
articles.teaser: Tea is a reason not to forget that we have each other. Even if you were out of touch for several years, an invitation to a tea would be the best way to meet.

profiles.name: Daun Kim
profiles.biography: Daun Kim is a sophomore from South Korea, majoring in Business, Organizations and Society and Social Research and Public Policy. She is passionate about reading books, writing anything, and designing social media accounts. She looks forward to working with amazing people!

articles.title: NYUAD Students Speak About the South Korean Presidential Election
articles.teaser: With South Korea having just elected a new president in an incredibly polarized election, we asked South Korean students at NYUAD for their thoughts on this messy race.

articles.title: Travelling, but Alone?
articles.teaser: Why would anyone travel alone? Read about the self-exploration that one can undertake during a solo trip in spring break.
